newsitem.title: CHILE: Chile sees lower inflation and growth next year.
newsitem.headline: Chile sees lower inflation and growth next year.

text.p: Chile can expect economic growth to cool off next year and inflation to drop to its lowest levels since the early 1960s, interim Central Bank President Jorge Marshall said.
Marshall, in the bank's report on 1997 economic projections to Congress, said the gross domestic product would expand by 5.5 to six percent, down from about seven percent this year.
The inflation target will be 5.5 percent, he said. That would be down from projections of about 6.5 percent this year and the lowest since 5.5 percent in 1960.

"For 1997, we expect to continue with a gradual reduction in inflation, accompanied by economic growth that will be significant but below the trend over the last few years," Marshall told lawmakers at Congress in Valparaso.
"This will allow us to continue on the path of stability, growth and development," he said.

He said solid financing of public spending, and moderation in the rise in both public and private spending, would be "necessary and complementary elements in monetary policy to achieve these macroeconomic goals."
Overall, Marshall's message was one of weaker growth, fiscal prudence and adverse conditions for export prices.

The government's current accounts deficit will widen to about $2.85 billion next year, or about four percent of GDP, he said. He attributed that deficit to this year's trade gap -- which he projected to be about $350 million -- and for higher service payments of about $300 million.
The balance of payments will post an overall surplus of $800 million next year, with a surplus in capital accounts more than making up for the current accounts deficit, said Marshall.
All told, Chile can expect a net capital inflow next year of $3.65 billion, about $3.1 billion of which are medium and long-term investments, he said.
New foreign investment should total next year about $1.7 billion, while new credit disbursements should total about $3.2 billion and amortizations about $1.8 billion, said Marshall.
